S2.T1.caption: TABLE I: Personalized layer performances of models with one fc and classifier across 10 datasets.
S2.T1.table:
Configuration CIFAR100 CIFAR10 CINIC10 EMNIST FMNIST M.N.A M.N.C MNIST SVHN T. ImageNet
fc1 40.346 85.265 80.27 92.968 96.548 94.192 92.897 98.827 92.990 22.345
classifier 43.647 84.556 78.792 93.635 96.750 96.017 94.376 99.336 93.873 28.201
references:
Studies like FedRep [14], FedBadu [15] and pFedSim [16], which adopt Central Kernel Alignment theory, typically define the first (n-1) layers of a neural network as the body and the last layer as personalized head.
However, our experiments with three different neural architectures across ten datasets (more details, please refer to Appendix -A) and as illustrated in Tables I–III, we observed that the pre-output fully connected (fc) layer performs better than the last layer (classifier) as the personalized layer in most cases.
We tested three versions of the LeNet5 [25] model, each with a different number of fc layers (2, 3, and 4 layers), across ten standard datasets. In the 2-layer model as shown in Table I, the classifier layer showed better results than the first fc layer (fc1) when used as the personalized layer. For the 3-layer LeNet5 as shown in Table II, the second fc layer (fc2) yielded the highest performance when used as the personalized layer across all datasets. With the 4-layer model as shown in Table III, both the fc2 and third fc layers (fc3) demonstrated superior performance compared to using the classifier as the personalized layer.
The results indicate that the classifier is not always the best choice.
This finding across these configurations highlights the need to develop a new mechanism for personalized layer selection.

We tested three versions of the LeNet5 [25] model, each with a different number of fc layers (2, 3, and 4 layers), across ten standard datasets. references: Federated Learning such as FedAvg

is a method designed for privacy-preserving data sharing while allowing the training of models across distributed devices.
However, traditional federated learning, mainly developed for scenarios with independent and identically distributed (iid) data distribution, struggles with slow convergence rates when applied to heterogeneous data distribution.
To address the challenge, heterogeneous federated learning has been proposed which encompasses several key aspects: (1)
Knowledge distillation
refines the exchange of information between global and local models, enhancing model generalization capabilities. (2)
Regularization terms
in the loss function
are employed to correct biases towards the global model, improving the robustness and universality of the global model. (3)
Similarity aggregation
, such as clustering
and multi-task learning

, enable more efficient information sharing among similar clients or tasks. Clustering groups like clients to learn individual models, whereas multi-task learning handles several client models simultaneously without forming distinct clusters. However, these methods often come with inherent drawbacks, such as relying on additional public datasets
, increased computational complexity
, and the risk of data leakage caused by additional parameter exposure
. One of the currently prominent approaches is (4)
Model decoupling
, which segregates models into shared
body
and personalized
head
. The body’s layers are shared among all clients, whereas the head is tailored based on each client’s data, striking a balance between global performance and individual client requirements.

S3.T5.table:
Symbol Description
𝒢​(𝒱,ℒ)𝒢𝒱ℒ\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{L}) the topology graph of the Cloud-edge system.
𝒱,ℒ𝒱ℒ\mathcal{V},\mathcal{L} Set of nodes and links for the system.
𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} The set of the edge clients.
N𝑁N The number of edge clients.
𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} The set of communication round.
𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} The local dataset with i𝑖i-th client.
𝒳i,𝒴isubscript𝒳𝑖subscript𝒴𝑖{\mathcal{X}_{i},\mathcal{Y}_{i}} The set of input data and label for i𝑖i-th client respectively.
nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} The data size of the i𝑖i-th client.
n𝑛n The total number of samples across all devices.
𝒞ksuperscript𝒞𝑘\mathcal{C}^{k} The set of clients participates in FL in round k𝑘k.
nksuperscript𝑛𝑘n^{k} The number of participated clients in round k𝑘k.
γ𝛾\gamma The join ratio of the edge clients in FL.
θGksuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝐺𝑘\theta_{G}^{k} The global model parameter in round k𝑘k.

references:
In this section, we give the preliminaries of the system model, federated Learning workflow with model decoupling, and Wasserstein distance.
For notation, scalars are represented by lowercase italic letters. Vectors and sets are denoted by lowercase bold italics and uppercase italics, respectively. Matrices are indicated with uppercase, italic, and bold fonts. The symbol ΔΔ\Delta represents the differential operator, while |⋅||\cdot| and ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| are used for the 1-norm and 2-norm, respectively. Table V lists the mathematical notations used in this paper.

references:
We compare the average model accuracy performance of our solution with other baselines in Table VI–VIII.
The results displayed in Table VI compare the average accuracy with α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1, where FedCMD exhibits outstanding performance across most datasets. Notably, FedCMD leads with significant margins in complex datasets like CIFAR100 and Tiny ImageNet, with remarkable accuracy improvements of 9.609% and 0.928% respectively over the second-best results.
Compared to established methods like FedBN, FedBabu, FedProx and FedDyn, FedCMD shows a marked improvement. For example, in the CIFAR10 dataset, our solution achieves an accuracy of 87.252%, which is 1.896% higher than the second-best, Local-Only. Similarly, in MedmNistC, our solution attains 94.588%, outperforming the nearest competitor, FedPer, by 1.735%.
The underlined results indicate the second-best performing methods, which offer strong competition in datasets like CINIC10. For instance, FedRep demonstrates robust performance in CINIC10 with an accuracy of 82.914%. These results suggest that while other methods have merits in specific conditions, FedCMD consistently leads in adapting to non-IID data in most federated learning environments.

In this context, the performance of our FedCMD method, while still leading in many cases.
Despite this, FedCMD remains the top performer in several datasets, notably achieving the highest accuracy in CIFAR10 at 71.331%, which is 6.872% higher than the second-best, FedRep.
In CIFAR100, FedCMD leads with 27.531%, outperforming pFedSim, the second-best, by a significant margin of 6.196%. This trend continues in Tiny ImageNet, where FedCMD’s accuracy of 14.561% is second only to pFedSim’s 16.725%.
Compared with other methods, our solution’s performance in datasets like FMNIST and MedmNistA is notably superior, with accuracy of 92.260% and 93.982% respectively, demonstrating its effectiveness even in less heterogeneous settings.
Despite the reduced heterogeneity, our solution continues to demonstrate robust performance across ten datasets with α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5.

Table VIII shows the average model accuracy with α=1.0𝛼1.0\alpha=1.0, indicating a more uniform data distribution than α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1 and α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5.
Despite this, FedCMD continues to lead in several datasets.
Notably, it achieves the highest accuracy in CIFAR10 at 64.508%, surpassing the second-best FedPer by 7.755%. In CIFAR100, FedCMD tops the list with an accuracy of 22.178%, showing a noticeable improvement over FedAvg. In datasets like FMNIST and MedmNistA, our solution outperforms others with the accuracy of 89.837% and 93.312%, respectively, underlining its effectiveness across varied settings.
FedCMD also demonstrates strong performance in Tiny ImageNet, achieving 12.537%, which, although not the highest, is close to the top performer, pFedSim. Compared to FedDyn, our solution shows a considerable advantage in datasets like CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, but a narrower lead in more uniform datasets like EMNIST and MNIST.
Overall, while FedCMD’s performance advantage diminishes in less heterogeneous scenarios (α=1.0𝛼1.0\alpha=1.0), it still shows notable effectiveness and robustness across a range of datasets.

S7.T9.caption: TABLE IX: Accuracy with different rounds of layer selection phase across ten datasets.
S7.T9.table:
Number of rounds 20 40 60 80 100
CIFAR10 84.076 87.427 87.422 87.51 87.117
CIFAR100 42.224 47.954 47.552 47.374 47.527
CINIC10 78.426 80.619 79.959 79.823 79.573
EMNIST 94.912 94.221 94.225 94.165 94.295
FMNIST 94.736 96.516 96.705 96.508 96.775
MedmNistA 95.204 96.362 96.517 96.418 96.444
MedmNistC 94.364 94.745 94.49 94.485 94.564
MNIST 99.266 99.289 99.313 99.281 99.259
SVHN 94.302 95.178 95.047 94.961 94.925
Tiny ImageNet 28.877 31.17 31.498 31.494 31.602
references:
Our study on the impact of communication rounds for the personalized layer selection phase in FedCMD reveals the relationship between the number of rounds and model accuracy. The data from Table IX shows that while most datasets benefit from an increased number of rounds, there are exceptions where fewer rounds also yield better results.
In most cases, a trend of increasing accuracy with more communication rounds is evident. For instance, CIFAR10 peaks at 87.51% with 80 rounds, FMNIST reaches 96.775% with 100 rounds, and Tiny ImageNet consistently improves, achieving its highest accuracy of 31.602% with 100 rounds. This trend suggests that more communication rounds generally lead to more accurate personalized layers, enhancing overall model performance.
However, some datasets such as EMNIST peak at 94.912% with just 20 rounds, indicating that fewer rounds can be more effective in certain scenarios. Similarly, CIFAR100 and MedmNistC show optimal performances at 40 rounds with an accuracy of 47.954% and 94.745%, respectively. These exceptions highlight that the relationship between communication rounds and accuracy is not always linear and can vary depending on the dataset’s characteristics.
Overall, while the general trend suggests that more communication rounds in FedCMD lead to better accuracy, the optimal number of rounds is highly dataset-dependent.

references: The foundational information pertaining to the datasets employed in our experiments is delineated in Table X. In order to ensure equitable comparisons across different methodologies, we adhere to the configuration established in pFedSim. This involves the segmentation of each dataset into 100 subsets, effectively constituting 100 clients. It is essential to note that the data distribution throughout the experiments is held constant, thus providing a consistent basis for evaluating the efficacy of diverse methods.
